{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's electrophoresis results show a high level of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) and a normal level of HbA2. This is indicative of beta-thalassemia major or beta-zero thalassemia, conditions where the production of normal adult hemoglobin (HbA) is impaired or absent. In these conditions, the body compensates by producing more HbF. On a peripheral smear, we would expect to see features of hemolytic anemia, such as anisocytosis (variation in red blood cell size), poikilocytosis (variation in red blood cell shape), and possibly basophilic stippling.
